dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, thanks. I guess I'm just feeling a bit worried about not making friends in college. It seems like everyone else is forming groups and I'm just kinda floating around.

That's understandable, starting college can be overwhelming. You feel worried because it seems like others are connecting more easily than you. What's your experience been like so far in trying to meet new people?

client(exploring): Well, I'm usually more comfortable making friends through classes and shared work. But it hasn't really clicked with my major or year group, so I'm finding it tough to connect. I'm not sure if it's just me or if I'm doing something wrong.

You seem to feel a bit uncertain because making connections hasn't been as smooth as you'd hoped, especially in classes where you usually find common ground. How have you approached connecting with others outside of your classes?

client(exploring): Honestly, I haven't really tried much outside of class. I'm not super outgoing, and it feels weird to just randomly approach people. I guess I'm stuck in my comfort zone and don't know where to start.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their concern about difficulty making friends in college and their discomfort in approaching others. The therapist has captured the essence of the client's thoughts and feelings, discussed the client's approach, and explored their comfort zone issues. There's a mutual understanding of the concern, but more is needed for agreed goals.

dialogue.statement: It's understandable to feel a bit out of your element when stepping outside your comfort zone. You feel hesitant because approaching new people can feel unfamiliar and challenging. What kinds of activities or interests do you enjoy that might help you meet others with similar interests?

client(exploring): I really like reading and gaming, but those don't always seem like the most social activities. I've thought about joining a club, but I don't know which one or how to get over the initial awkwardness of showing up alone.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared detailed thoughts and feelings about their struggle with making friends, revealing context about their comfort zones and interests. The conversation has successfully built rapport and explored mutual goals regarding social engagement. It's appropriate to advance to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: Joining a club could be a great way to meet others with shared interests, even if it feels awkward at first. What would it be like for you to imagine finding a club that combines reading or gaming, and how might connecting with others there align with your hopes for college?

client(reflecting): I guess it would be nice to meet people who enjoy the same things I do. It might make it easier to start conversations if we have something in common right from the start. Plus, it could help me feel more involved and less like I'm just on the sidelines.

Engaging with people who share your interests could certainly ease those initial conversations and help you feel more connected. How do you envision your college experience changing if you started to feel more involved and connected with others?

client(reflecting): I think I'd feel a lot more settled and less stressed about the whole social aspect. It'd be nice to have a group to hang out with or do things together, you know? It might even make me enjoy college more overall.

therapist(guiding): Feeling settled and connected could really enhance your college experience and reduce that social stress. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about taking a step towards finding and joining a club that interests you?
client(reflecting): Maybe like a 5 or 6? I mean, it's still a bit intimidating, but I think I can try if I find the right club. I just need to push myself a little to actually go and see how it goes.

statement.reasoning: The client has shown Change Talk by considering joining a club, expressed a desire to feel more connected, and identified potential benefits of this change. Confidence was rated at 5 or 6, showing room for growth but indicating some readiness. Ambivalence has decreased as the client envisions positive outcomes of engaging with others.

dialogue.statement: Taking that first step can indeed be challenging, but it's great to hear that you're willing to give it a try if you find the right club. What are a couple of small steps you might take to explore potential clubs and gradually increase your comfort level with joining one?

client(choosing): I guess I could start by checking out the list of clubs online or maybe ask around to see what my classmates are into. Then, maybe I could attend a meeting or an event just to get a feel for it before committing. That way, I can see if it feels like a good fit without too much pressure.

Exploring clubs online and talking to classmates are excellent starting points, allowing you to ease into the process. How might you track your progress and handle any nerves that might come up along the way?

client(choosing): I could set small goals for myself, like checking out one club's meeting each week or talking to one new person. If I start feeling nervous, maybe I can remind myself that it's okay to feel that way and focus on the fact that I'm doing this to make my college experience better. Having a friend to go with me the first time might help too, if I can find someone.

Setting small goals like attending one club meeting a week or talking to one new person are excellent strategies for building confidence gradually. Inviting a friend along can definitely help ease those nerves. How would you like to keep track of your goals and celebrate your successes as you take these steps?

client(choosing): I think I could keep a simple journal or maybe use a notes app on my phone to track what clubs I check out and who I meet. Celebrating could be as simple as treating myself to a favorite snack or taking some time to relax with a game or book I enjoy. Just small things that make me feel good about making progress.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified clear steps to explore clubs and manage any nerves, alongside strategies for progress tracking and self-reward, indicating readiness for action. They express willingness to initiate change with plans to overcome potential barriers. Confidence level and action steps suggest readiness to advance.

dialogue.statement: Jotting down your experiences in a journal or notes app is a fantastic way to keep track of your journey and reflect on your progress. Treating yourself to something you enjoy, like a favorite snack or downtime with a game or book, sounds like a rewarding way to celebrate your achievements. You've identified some thoughtful steps and coping strategies to help make these new experiences more manageable. Remember, every small step you take is bringing you closer to feeling more settled and connected at college. Your willingness to explore and try new things is truly commendable. As you continue on this path, know that you're not alone; support is always available when you need it.

client(terminating): Thanks, that really helps me feel more hopeful about all this. I'll definitely keep what we talked about in mind and try to take it one step at a time. It's nice knowing there's support if I need it.

statement.reasoning: The session included a summary of goals, steps, and coping strategies. The client expressed hopefulness and plans to proceed with small, manageable steps. Closure was naturally invited, indicating readiness to end the session.

concern:
title: Not making friends in and out of major after first semester
I'm a pretty reserved person and like making friends through class and mutual work. I don't really fit in with the rest of my major, especially not my year, so that didn't work out all that well last semester. I was told by an upper classman in a different major who is very outgoing and goes out all of the time that I have to make friends now bc if I don't put myself out there everyone will gather into groups and be less willing to let you in. Is that really true? I'm not even shy, I jsut don't really work like that, but now I'm really worried I'm going to spend college alone
